articles.headline: White House Warnings Over Russia Strain Ukraine-U.S. Partnership
articles.snippet: While Ukraine’s president complained about “acute and burning” warnings from Washington, the Pentagon issued a dire new appraisal asserting Russia has amassed enough troops to invade his entire country.
articles.abstract: While Ukraine’s president complained about “acute and burning” warnings from Washington, the Pentagon issued a dire new appraisal asserting Russia has amassed enough troops to invade his entire country.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukrainian officials sharply criticized the Biden administration Friday for its ominous warnings of an imminent Russian attack, saying they had needlessly spread alarm, even as a new Pentagon assessment said Russia was now positioned to go beyond a limited incursion and invade all of Ukraine.
articles.byline: By Michael Schwirtz and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: As Breyer Pondered Retirement, Biden Bet on a Hands-Off Strategy
articles.snippet: The president believed pressuring the court’s oldest justice to retire might backfire. A chorus of liberals took a different approach.
articles.abstract: The president believed pressuring the court’s oldest justice to retire might backfire. A chorus of liberals took a different approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden had hoped that Justice Stephen G. Breyer would retire soon. But as he and his advisers waited for the most senior member of the Supreme Court’s liberal wing to make up his mind, the president had made it clear: No one was to do anything to pressure him.
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: As Russian Troops Mass in Belarus, a Ukraine Border Is Largely Undefended
articles.snippet: From the border, it’s a fast 140 miles down a newly paved highway to Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, but only a few troops stand guard.
articles.abstract: From the border, it’s a fast 140 miles down a newly paved highway to Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, but only a few troops stand guard.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOVI YARYLOVYCHI BORDER CROSSING, Ukraine — On the other side of this border in northern Ukraine, not visible through the thick pine and birch forests that crowd the E-95 highway but noticeable to passing truckers, a force is gathering in Belarus more potent than anything seen in the country since the fall of the Soviet Union, officials and military analysts say.

articles.headline: Buy GameStop, Fight Injustice. Just Don’t Sell.
articles.snippet: One year in the trenches of the meme stock revolution.
articles.abstract: One year in the trenches of the meme stock revolution.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been a year since Mat Bowen, who was the pastor of a small church in Gibson City, Ill., had the dream — the one where Elon Musk, the head of Tesla, urged him to buy Dogecoin.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard, Emily Flitter and Anupreeta Das

articles.headline: U.S. Sanctions Aimed at Russia Could Take a Wide Toll
articles.snippet: The boldest measures that President Biden is threatening to deter an invasion of Ukraine could roil the entire Russian economy — but also those of other nations.
articles.abstract: The boldest measures that President Biden is threatening to deter an invasion of Ukraine could roil the entire Russian economy — but also those of other nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The most punishing sanctions that U.S. officials have threatened to impose on Russia could cause severe inflation, a stock market crash and other forms of financial panic that would inflict pain on its people — from billionaires to government officials to middle-class families.
articles.byline: By Michael Crowley and Edward Wong

articles.headline: Democrats Decried Dark Money. Then They Won With It in 2020.
articles.snippet: A New York Times analysis reveals how the left outdid the right at raising and spending millions from undisclosed donors to defeat Donald Trump and win power in Washington.
articles.abstract: A New York Times analysis reveals how the left outdid the right at raising and spending millions from undisclosed donors to defeat Donald Trump and win power in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: For much of the last decade, Democrats complained — with a mix of indignation, frustration and envy — that Republicans and their allies were spending hundreds of millions of difficult-to-trace dollars to influence politics.
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Shane Goldmacher

articles.headline: As Storms Intensify, the Job of TV Weather Person Gets More Serious
articles.snippet: Once considered comic relief to anchors, television meteorologists are making it clear to viewers that they are covering a crisis in real time.
articles.abstract: Once considered comic relief to anchors, television meteorologists are making it clear to viewers that they are covering a crisis in real time.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the remains of Hurricane Ida dumped historic levels of rain in the Northeast last year, ABC News’s chief meteorologist, Ginger Zee, stood in front of a collapsed bridge in New Jersey and gave viewers of “Good Morning America” a clear warning.

articles.headline: Black Women in Law Feel Pride and Frustration Ahead of Court Nominee
articles.snippet: As Biden prepares to nominate the first Black woman to the nation’s highest court, members of this small, elite group are watching with complicated emotions.
articles.abstract: As Biden prepares to nominate the first Black woman to the nation’s highest court, members of this small, elite group are watching with complicated emotions.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Race affects our lives in countless ways. To read more stories on race from The New York Times, sign up here for our Race/Related newsletter.]
articles.byline: By Tariro Mzezewa and Audra D. S. Burch

articles.headline: Living by the Code: In China, Covid-Era Controls May Outlast the Virus
articles.snippet: The country has instituted a wide range of high-tech controls on society as part of a mostly successful effort to stop the virus. The consequences may endure.
articles.abstract: The country has instituted a wide range of high-tech controls on society as part of a mostly successful effort to stop the virus. The consequences may endure.
articles.lead_paragraph: The police had warned Xie Yang, a human rights lawyer, not to go to Shanghai to visit the mother of a dissident. He went to the airport anyway.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley, Vivian Wang and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Inflation and Deficits Don’t Dim the Appeal of U.S. Bonds
articles.snippet: Treasury rates remain strikingly low, partly because of the safety government debt offers corporations and retirees. Whether that endures is crucial to federal spending.
articles.abstract: Treasury rates remain strikingly low, partly because of the safety government debt offers corporations and retirees. Whether that endures is crucial to federal spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: Markets have been in upheaval. The Federal Reserve is taking steps to cool off the economy, as questions loom about the course of the recovery. And headlines are proclaiming that government bond yields are near two-year highs.

articles.headline: For Ketanji Brown Jackson, View of Criminal Justice Was Shaped by Family
articles.snippet: The story of an uncle’s cocaine conviction formed only part of Judge Jackson’s understanding of the system’s complexities. She is now seen as a contender to be President Biden’s Supreme Court pick.
articles.abstract: The story of an uncle’s cocaine conviction formed only part of Judge Jackson’s understanding of the system’s complexities. She is now seen as a contender to be President Biden’s Supreme Court pick.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Ketanji Brown Jackson does not much talk about it, but when she was a college freshman, an uncle was sentenced to life in prison — a Black man, like so many others, handed a severe punishment during the war-on-drugs era.
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: The Hard-Line Russian Advisers Who Have Putin’s Ear
articles.snippet: Three reactionary security officials dedicated to “traditional values” and restoring Soviet glory will figure prominently in the decision whether to invade Ukraine.
articles.abstract: Three reactionary security officials dedicated to “traditional values” and restoring Soviet glory will figure prominently in the decision whether to invade Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The West is legalizing marriage between people and animals. Ukraine’s leaders are as bad as Hitler, and the country’s nationalists are “nonhumans.”

articles.headline: Campaigning to Oversee Elections, While Denying the Last One
articles.snippet: Brazenly partisan candidates who insist that Donald Trump won the 2020 election are transforming races for the once-obscure office of secretary of state.
articles.abstract: Brazenly partisan candidates who insist that Donald Trump won the 2020 election are transforming races for the once-obscure office of secretary of state.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Nearly two dozen Republicans who have publicly questioned or disputed the results of the 2020 election are running for secretary of state across the country, in some cases after being directly encouraged by allies of former President Donald J. Trump.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina, Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: Migrant Worker’s Tale of Inequality Grips China, Then Is Erased
articles.snippet: A man with Covid revealed a parallel universe to well-off Chinese and became a symbol of inequality. The government found him inconvenient to its narrative.
articles.abstract: A man with Covid revealed a parallel universe to well-off Chinese and became a symbol of inequality. The government found him inconvenient to its narrative.
articles.lead_paragraph: He visited 28 places in the first 18 days of 2022, including a puppet theater, a few luxury residential compounds and a shopping mall in the heart of China’s equivalent of Silicon Valley.
